text: @grohlerbear @qmukingston @Lc402 @IDontBlog I am not defending this jackass, but on this specific point in the UK pants = underwear. It’s a common misunderstanding and source of hilarity, like when a friend moved to the UK and asked if she should wear pants or a dress to an event and was met with confused horror
@qmukingston @Lc402 @grohlerbear @IDontBlog Pants = trousers if you are British. They are not talking about underwear. Blood leaking through to your pants/trousers happens

@AnupamAich4 @FromPhDtoLife Also, in US academia, applying to “peer” institutions that “count” as a competing offer (and have openings in your niche field in that year) almost always means applying to uproot and move hours and states away. Academic women are more likely to be geographically constrained.

@AnupamAich4 @FromPhDtoLife But is it *the only* way to get a raise in those industries? Would a high performer, who wants to stay, be told by their boss, who also wants to retain them, to go apply for other jobs and come back with outside offers as the only way they could ever get a raise?
@FullJackalope @PhDhurtBrain I resemble this genre
@DGlaucomflecken I love this. Now I need someone to do it again, but for grants. And maybe tenure 🙃

@milkthistled @HarlequinHatter @JoshuaPotash It is often effectively impossible. Example: There are medications that often cause both weight gain and Type II diabetes (directly, not just through weight gain), including most antipsychotics. What tradeoff would you recommend between physical and mental health in these cases?

@HarlequinHatter @milkthistled @JoshuaPotash But let’s say it was a moral failing (it isn’t) so what? Are we in the business of punishing people who take imperfect care of their health, or get in careless accidents etc. with bankruptcy or death now, and worse, thinking that that’s somehow morally just?
@milkthistled @JoshuaPotash Separate from, as noted, that this is not the group that typically needs insulin
@bussy_hound @frankhenn Why are you responding to a post about insulin prices, something you don’t care about then?

@milkthistled @JoshuaPotash So, it sounds like you think their diabetes is caused by their “lifestyle”, and therefore they deserve to be ransomed for all they’re worth or die, or possibly that they just deserve to get very ill and die period? Am I misunderstanding your point?

@Texjannie @QueenWheelerRe1 @alexhhart Hopefully. But sometimes, even in that very best case parental scenario, you can grow up thinking that sure, your parents love you and they mean well, but the overwhelming weight of social evidence suggests that you have the kind of personality that only a parent could love 🙃
@zilla_jones @BlasianNation @alexhhart Even simpler, they hand out the invites at school and out one in everyone else’s desk (that one happened to me)

@zilla_jones @BlasianNation @alexhhart Kids talk, sometimes maliciously, but not even always. If all 20 other kids in your 5th grade class are spending lunch that week talking excitedly about a party you haven’t heard about, occasionally looking in your direction and then shushing each other, well there it is.

@Texjannie @QueenWheelerRe1 @alexhhart If you are the weird kid who never or rarely gets invited, you already know that not everybody is going to like you. That’s a given. But the question you are often left with is, is anybody going to?

@SherryfromTex @ConceitedButch @Marinebio123 @Texjannie @alexhhart I was the only kid not invited, and I  knew. Even if no one else says it outright, which they often do, everyone is talking about the party, because everyone is excited. Or, you overhear them whispering about not inviting only you, because you’re so weird, no one wants you there

@barnaclebear @dranniehickox @DrDBeech @BipolarBlogger I have ADHD, and the one I like is to breathe in through my nose, and breathe out through pursed lips, like I’m blowing up a balloon. It slows down my breathing and makes the exhale longer than the inhale, without counting etc. I don’t even really have to think about it anymore

@ljudlega @YehudisFletcher @DrJessTaylor To some extent yes—there’s a feedback loop between the mental and physical responses, which is self-reinforcing. The medication helps you experience the stressor with less physical panic. This can be part of weakening the association, replacing it with the experience of being ok

@ljudlega @YehudisFletcher @DrJessTaylor How about if the response to the stressor is distressing and unhelpful. Full fight/flight response to something that isn’t a current threat at all, but reminds you of a large threat you experienced in the past.  Addressing that doesn’t preclude addressing the underlying trauma
@JoshuaNeedleman @TraumaSoapBoxes I have never, not once, thought about the contacts or the menstrual cup in this context. I can’t decide if I should thank or curse this thread now

@FionaSoper @RainaBrands I’m pretty sure that this particular example is written this way to prevent women from having their benefits stolen by their (abusive) exes. In the US I actually know multiple women who’ve had to fight completely non-custodial dads who keep claiming the kids on their taxes first

@AuntimusPrime @danidonovan If I take lamotrigine at night I consistently get nightmares that are unusually vivid and memorable and also unusually weird and just  disturbing. This is actually a known thing with lamotrigine oddly enough. So, morning it is.
@SergioTx_ @danidonovan Meee toooo

@whitepeakwell I understood the criticism as about suggesting something that has almost certainly already been suggested 100s of times before. “Have you tried going for a walk” can sound condescending, because yes, they probably have tried, and if not, not because they don’t know it’s an option

I’m thinking of upgrading from a mostly Twitter lurker who doesn’t entirely understand the etiquette, and occasionally steps in it in the comments, to a Twitter poster, who also occasionally steps in it, but more directly. This seems like a solid plan, what could go wrong? https://t.co/b0dRWdCSz1

@alahav I appreciate the motivation. I wonder if telling people who prefer/need to work after hours that they can ask for an extension (ahead of time) causes less stress than telling students who’d rather not work after hours that they can hand it in early.  Would be interesting to study
@ambernoelle Also, my mom used to buy fat-fee ice cream that DIDN’T MELT. It kind of…desiccated? It dried up into something like old smushed cotton candy

@ambernoelle I rarely drink soda, but when I do it’s still always diet, not for any dieting reasons (no dieting for me), but because I grew up on one diet soda and the sugar stuff still tastes weird to me.
@consensualhugs @ambernoelle Oh God, I had blocked the existence of those from my mind. The taste just came back to me fill force. There was an intense chemical aftertaste too

@Iamwilter @ProfLikeSubst Sadly, at two different faculty jobs I have been explicitly told that the 60% of my official workload that isn’t research counts for exactly nothing in tenure and promotion. Also, business hours are for teaching and meetings, evenings and weekends are for getting my research done

@ProfLikeSubst @realDLeblang In my field it’s increasingly common for grad and postdoc trainees to supervise undergrad researchers, so they get some hands-on management experience there, though it’s not a given. It’s very controversial to even allow a grad student to teach their own class though
@imbeggingyousma @aishku @ByKatieDavidson @WoodyLuvsCoffee To be fair, I’d much rather a knock on the door from a stranger than a cold call from most loved ones 😛

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I don’t want to derail this thread into a discussion of ADHD, but suffice it to say, I believe that it’s that simple—for you. “Have you tried just putting it in your calendar?” is to ADHD as “have you tried taking a walk in the fresh air?” is to depression. Yes, we’ve tried that

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife The other 2.5% is that I do it gladly for *students*, but I don’t think that writing 100s of undergrad letters unpaid is a service I do gladly for the *university*. The kool aid that the life of the mind is so rarefied that we don’t need paid for our work is a problem throughout

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I agree with you 95%. I can’t even make it to my own flights, medical and visa appointments on the right date and time. I have a significant disability that people constantly make into a moral issue. I got my hackles up to quickly as a result. It’s not about me, so I’ll bow out

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife But,as mentioned elsewhere, I’m not interested in digging myself in on the side of current power structures, and misread the thread’s intent. It is certainly not students’ fault that the university doesn’t pay me to write letters for them

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I absolutely 100% do consider it service. What I am saying is that unfortunately my university explicitly does not (and that is not an exception). It cannot be included in accounting for my time or effort under “service” or “teaching” on my annual evaluation forms, for instance.

@CodeBug88 @PensionedA @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife Yes, as noted elsewhere, I got my hackles up and misread the intent of the thread (which, surprise, isn’t about me :p). I have no interest in digging myself into a hole on the side of defending current academic power structures . Mental health in academia is it’s own story.
@samjlord @timgill924 Thanks, as noted I’ll stop digging myself a hole of faculty privilege over here. https://t.co/KTpMvcRJBh

@samjlord @timgill924 Anyway, I’ll back down, I’m really not trying to dig in on the plight of tenure track faculty relative to grad students and others in precarious and exploited academic positions. I may have missed the forest for the “calendars are really not my strong suit” trees in jumping in

@samjlord @timgill924 It is not. I think I misread where this thread was coming from. There’s a distinction between writing for grad students, which is absolutely an obligation, and writing 100s of undergrad letters. Also, my “very ADHD and doing my damn best” hackles may have gone up a bit too much

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I had to create a throwaway account because I’m so worried I will lose my job if my colleagues see me following mental health accounts, let alone find out that I have ADHD or am bipolar, but yes, my ADHD is clearly performative and not something that profoundly impacts my life

@CodeBug88 @PensionedA @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I have pretty literally never said no to writing a glowing letter for a grad student, but I was referring to the 100s of undergraduate letters I write every year. The system is broken and biased, so I try to write for everyone. Sometimes I need a reminder, because I am a human

@PensionedA @CodeBug88 @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I’m talking about undergrads, but I think it can be reasonable to ask for a reminder. Unfortunately, many parts of my job are not accounted for in how I am evaluated or paid. Writing letters is explicitly not considered to be research, teaching or service for instance

@PensionedA @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife Also, students are not my employer. I am very happy to write letters, a time consuming favour I provide for students, not the other way around. If they are asking me to spend time writing them a thoughtful, supportive letter (usually after hours, unpaid), I can ask for a reminder

@PensionedA @kurtjgray @FromPhDtoLife I do my best, but professors can also have ADHD, and when you are sending out 100+ letters per recommendation season (20 students, 5+ grad/med school applications each, often double that many students or letters per student) mistakes can happen.

@Bored_Insomniac @felineconcubine @quitabunnies @AITA_online And the literal definition of marriage used to involve only a man and a woman. “MAR'RIAGE, noun [Latin mas, maris.] The act of uniting a man and woman for life; wedlock; the legal union of a man and woman for life.” Webster, 1828. We know better now. Our better natures prevailed

@biomilkveronica @felineconcubine @quitabunnies @AITA_online Men are usually, but not always, sexually attracted to women, and women usually but not always to men. People are usually, but not always, right handed. We often think the minority outcome of human variation is unnatural, sinister or threatening, until our better natures prevail

@felineconcubine @quitabunnies @AITA_online Biologically female people usually, but not always (and I don’t just mean because of hysterectomy), have a uterus. Biologically female people are usually, but not always, women. Women are usually, but not always, biologically female. It’s actually pretty straight forward.
@ThomasBenn34 @awaisaftab @Altostrata @JDaviesPhD This, of all comments, earned me my first ever block? Do I at least get a prize or something? I’m new to this.
@JewWhoHasItAll @infinitezero600 @gzuckier @hughlaurie I’m being a stats nerd, not critiquing your math, it’s all spherical cows :p

@JewWhoHasItAll @infinitezero600 @gzuckier @hughlaurie If it’s the probability of when the rain will start, then it’s not binomial because there’s only one occurrence, so it would be a categorical distribution, but then the probability of choosing each hour as the start hour should be 1/(# hours) if they really are uniform

@JewWhoHasItAll @infinitezero600 @gzuckier @hughlaurie That works if it’s the probability of whether it will be raining that hour, and you think the hours are independent of each other. But an assumption of independence probably doesn’t make much sense (the probability of rain at 10am is very dependent on whether it’s raining at 9am)
@hughlaurie I always assumed it was the chance it will be raining at that time of day

@Lukigi16 @amackenz2048 @scottjla @Gavin_Cawley @hughlaurie But not always 50% of the time. You either had guacamole with your last meal or you didn’t, but you probably don’t have it half the time. You’re either right handed or left handed, but half of all people are not left handed. It’s either Saturday or it isn’t but…

@ThomasBenn34 @awaisaftab @Altostrata @JDaviesPhD I am a random account on Twitter because the world in general, and academia in particular, are full of stigma and bias, and I don’t even feel that I can follow mental illness related content under my own name, for fear of colleagues noticing, let alone post about mental illness

@ThomasBenn34 @awaisaftab @Altostrata @JDaviesPhD I may experience diagnosis differently than some others, but I found a clear label indicating a shared category of experience, with at least some causality outside of my own personality and volition, with clear strategies to try (not only, or even mostly, medication), helpful.

@ThomasBenn34 @awaisaftab @Altostrata @JDaviesPhD Being diagnosed was amazing. You know that book “you mean I’m not lazy, stupid or crazy?” That’s what it felt like. I’d known something wasn’t right well before diagnosis, but now there was a tractable reason beyond “well, I guess that’s just who you are, and what you’re like”

@the_tweedy @wintersong I’m a cis woman who never once considered my butt hair until age 30ish when I kept hearing other people talking about waxing it, tried shaving it once, found it extraordinarily itchy, and went back to never thinking about it. But, I do very, very little about body hair in general

@Doreltwttt @Madsp4 @bvmaryp Already? Millennials are ages 26-42, when did you expect them to buy homes if they were ever going to? “17% of homeowners are millennials. 42% of millennials were homeowners at age 30, compared to 48% of gen X and 51% of baby boomers at the same age.” https://t.co/xENcrh0qQx

@patriotnot45 @debbiedwood @DrHarryThomas Yes, the incidence of severe allergies has increased over the past couple of decades. There are a variety of theories, including but not limited to lack of early exposure (ironically, the advice to not feed common allergens until age 2 or older may have made things worse)

@TheBookN3rd @Its_Miss_Riss @AShihipar This is backwards. A parent who steals diapers, laundry detergent and food isn’t a a thief who happens to  have kids. They’re a parent who must resort to stealing to keep their children clean and fed. It’s a damning commentary on our lack of social safety net, not on the parent

@LauretteSTucker @DGlaucomflecken Except when that salary is paid off of a grant, and the university is pocketing 60% of that grant money as “overhead”. I am expected to work 12 months a year, but I am paid for only 9 months by my institution. Better write a couple more grants if I want to get paid for the rest

@Kaufm020 @DGlaucomflecken @MarcusGPrescott Peer review under the current system is entirely voluntary, it is already done by other researchers for free. I don’t see why this would change for alternative journals published by the academic community, and in fact it hasn’t been a problem for those that already exist

@RedPill206 @DGlaucomflecken @Mark_MNLocal Money isn’t everything, but it sure is helpful to fund a research program. What if I got some of that money to help pay my grad students and postdocs, and pay for research costs, and then I could spend less time death-matching all the other researchers for pennies from the NSF
@MarcusPun @PokeItOutbby @IDoTheThinking There is also a vacancy tax in Vancouver, and one just coming into effect in Toronto

Am I the only one who likes it when a therapist occasionally runs a couple minutes late? You mean, even organized people who seem like they have it really, really together are sometimes late? So, maybe it’s not an unforgivable moral failure when I am? It gives my ADHD self life

@VeronikaEliz10 @TracyPe36638706 @ceekayem0 @rascallycake @KatiePennick My reaction was primarily to the statement that the mother chose to have her kids, but the wheelchair user did not choose to have her disability. All of them should have access to the bus, it’s a distraction to make it about the buggy, I am very much on the side of the OP here
@Rebmnmny @ambernoelle This is one of just about 3 or 4 fields where this is true. Should everybody really be a nurse, software engineer or accountant?

@VeronikaEliz10 @TracyPe36638706 @ceekayem0 @rascallycake @KatiePennick No she should not, it should not be a zero sum game, where we pit people’s needs against each other to distract from the overall inadequacy of the services. The children are also people and did not ask to be born, or to be young and helpless at this stage of development

@DannyBednar @marisollebron This is talking about the professors (not their own PhDs). Harvard is known for never tenuring anybody. Being an assistant professor there is often referred to as a 7 year postdoc. Their tenured faculty are all already tenured superstars poached from other universities
@DGlaucomflecken When did my husband take up medicine?
@JewWhoHasItAll @CraigTinsky Oops, I see that’s been well covered 😜
@johnmoe https://t.co/P5EVlvZgIE
@joshgondelman Yes

@neilhimself A flashlight didn’t occur to me, so I strained my eyes reading by the light of the slightly ajar door. I thought pretending to be asleep was implausible, so if someone walked by I pretended to play with my stuffed animals, which resulted in the poor animals being banned from bed
@RustyinCBus @mygiantrobot So, to make sure I understand the problem, instead of ordering another employee to take her shift for this one time exception, you had to ask, and someone agreed?

@DayNate89 @Woodgirl1977 @joestarr187 Because we’re living in a terrible world over here in the US where many people are left only with die, keep experiencing that much pain, or go into unthinkable life destroying debt as their options, but sometimes they’re not offered that last one with the life destroying debt 😞

@Ebonyteach I also try to take my graduating masters and PhD students out to lunch one on one, because I want to demonstrate that I appreciate their tremendous achievement completing a thesis/dissertation, and their time spent in my lab, and that I support them in moving on in their careers

@Ebonyteach They were usually at a restaurant for brunch or lunch, but I sometimes hosted. My advisors in undergrad and grad school would also host group events at their houses occasionally. It made me feel included and like more than just a warm body in the lab, which is why I did the same

@Ebonyteach This is interesting to think about. I have social events for my lab once a semester, at least during pre-COVID times, and I’ve found it’s important for team cohesion and morale. I’ve gotten a lot of feedback about how disconnected the students feel since we stopped having them.
@AnaMardoll I was just recently contemplating the fact that this was one of my favorite movies at age 11. Watched it a million times, we owned it on VHS.

@Me_Marcel_and_I @PDArebellion @mstinson1234 @tinyintern There are measurements marked directly inside the bowl of the rice cooker, but I don’t find them as reliable as a measuring cup, and sometimes hard to read once I’ve put the rice in

@Me_Marcel_and_I @PDArebellion @mstinson1234 @tinyintern I have a very fancy rice cooker, I can’t be relied on to watch the rice! It’s moved about 5 times with me including between countries. The measuring cup, if it ever had one, did not make it. Is the cup marked for both water and rice together? Otherwise, I don’t understand.

@ganglads_ I went back to grad school at 27, a lot of my classmates were 21 or 22. Honestly, I barely ever thought about it. It meant many of my friends were 5-6 years younger, and my husband is 6 years older, so he ended up with a lot of friends a decade younger meeting people through me.

@Palitato @PDArebellion @mstinson1234 @tinyintern I do better if there’s a hook directly next to the door so I can hang them up before entering, but if I make it into the house without hanging them up, then they could be on any flat surface on any floor, in any pocket, or occasionally still in the door the next time I need them.

@calimccammon @Toaster_Pastry Wow, some of the answers to this. I can’t reach my PCP directly even during business hours. I can leave a message and get a call back from staff in a day or two if it’s not urgent (told to go to urgent care if it is), but not from the doctor. A phone call requires an appointment
@scaredofbugz @calimccammon @Toaster_Pastry I love that. But also, you and nobody else!

@PDArebellion @mstinson1234 @tinyintern Part of the problem for the rice and the bread is that I sometimes make half/double, so if I remember amounts I previously used, but not ratios, it’s useless. See also: 1 vs 2 boxes of Mac n’ cheese, brownies etc. Also, if you regularly forget everything, you never know you know

@PDArebellion @mstinson1234 @tinyintern Nope. I have to double check. I also can’t learn to hang up my keys when I first enter the house. But, I can sing the complete Disney’s The Gummy Bears cartoon theme song lyrics, as well as most of the songs from Animaniacs by heart, those are seared into my brain since the ‘90s

@mstinson1234 @tinyintern Neither of those things has ever happened to me. Also, today I googled the water to rice ratio for white rice, to double check that it really is 2:1. I am 40 years old, and I cook rice at least once a week.
@Val_Hawks @ilyseh See also https://t.co/y0ERKDTPH9

@Val_Hawks @ilyseh European Jews were seen as a race by the Nazis. Nazism was racial. That’s why anyone with even a Jewish grandparent, and no matter how assimilated, was rounded up and murdered. Race is a construct and so European Jews can be seen as white in some contexts and racialized in others
@gatodelsol83 @DanaSchwartzzz @neilhimself This thread may also be helpful https://t.co/y0ERKDTPH9

@tylerblack32 Other. There were ways that it was not safe (lots of bullying), but neither was home, and I was lucky to have a couple very close supportive friends who got me through that time, and some teachers who really cared about me, and made me feel worthwhile. So, not safe, but *safer*

@Jason_Buck @johnmoe but it would be very rare for the correct answer on guess #2 to be purely deductive (there is only one possible remaining 5 letter word based on included/excluded letters). Getting it in 2 is fun, but it’s not proof the game is easy—starting word choice doesn’t solve the puzzle.
@johnmoe Is that a problem? But also, I have an increasing list of made up personal constraints on my word choices, and I still love it 😛

@TuomasPernu @TFLangkaas Also, unless you are a dualist, these are just differing levels of explanation. If it changes mental activity, then it must change brain activity. While it is easier to conceptualise some interventions psychologically, if they are effective they ultimately have a physical impact

@TuomasPernu @TFLangkaas But many physical diseases respond to behavioral interventions. Change in diet for celiac disease or high cholesterol. Physical therapy for injuries. Increased exercise for Type 2 diabetes. Is exercise a “psychological”or “biological” intervention for depression?

@jessball724 @riala4change @harlemwrlddd @blackboikei Our previous school district had rules about total absences, regardless of reason. You needed permission from the principal or school board for missing more than something like 10-14 days in a school year or more than 3 in a row. Among other issues, they lose money for absences.
Just had a new couples’ therapist tell me that my husband and I are both unusually opaque to him, but in unique ways, so I guess at least we’re not boring 🤨

@LiftedVay @Exallium @TE_AMO_COURT I know someone who had a job offer retracted that way recently, over the same number. Asked for $145,000, turned out their max was $130,000. Said they’d decided they couldn’t afford him and were going to move on.
@SarahKomedy Some of us turned 40, continue to throw our bodies around like we’re 20, and are then somehow surprised, and a bit offended, every single time, as we suffer the consequences afterwards

@Exallium @TE_AMO_COURT The job had a budget. If this person had “shot for the moon” and asked for $200k they wouldn’t have hired her.  It’s a stupid game of “guess the real number”, based on a combination of tacit knowledge and privilege, and the company is apparently playing to screw the employee.

@MimiChase007 @Kariisaacs @MikeDrucker I don’t understand what you mean. I didn’t hate my experience? I’m just explaining why opening up to anyone, even a therapist, who is supposed to be “safe”, especially at the beginning before you’ve gotten to know them, and they’ve gotten to know you, can be hard for some of us.

@Kariisaacs @MimiChase007 @MikeDrucker I have both thoughts at once! (1) my thoughts and problems will be horrifying and offputting, even to a professional whose job it is to hear them (or maybe *I* will be horrifying and offputting) (2) yet they will also judge me because my life is pretty good, why am I such a mess?

@BlackshepSusan @kloppquotes @PaulMinotMD What, to you, is the distinction between a drug and a medicine? Anti-hypertensives lower everyone’s blood pressure. Insulin lowers everyone’s blood sugar (very dangerous for non-diabetics). The effects of many drugs are universal, yet disease or symptom modifying for some people.

@LiaBoBia @keara_dunne @TribalSpaceCat @deadeyebrakeman Hah, I was going to say there are no *low-maintenance* flattering bangs for curly hair, but ran out of characters. But then, what is low maintenance with curly hair.

@MimiChase007 @MikeDrucker First you have to believe that they want to help you, and it’s not just that they want to help people in general, but wow, look at you, you’re a real mess, and then that they’ll still want to help you after hearing what’s inside your brain. For some of us that can be hard 🙃

@sarahhollowell This is interesting! My interpretation as a kid was that yeah, he tried hard to change, but the point of the movie was that it’s just not realistic for a guy to change for a girl, so in the end she saved him from having to change by changing herself instead. Will have to rewatch!

@WayneHerrick1 @JakeAnbinder As others have mentioned, a democracy falling into totalitarianism, tyranny, and persecution and mass murder of its own citizens in modern times, not to mention launching a world war, seems worthy of close historical inspection. I studied The Great Leap Forward in 9th grade.

@WayneHerrick1 @JakeAnbinder So, do you apply the same standard to all of European history? No Greeks and Romans for you? No Middle Ages? No Spanish Inquisition? Why would that be relevant to Americans, right?  Also, I am an American whose grandparents were Holocaust survivors, and I’m far from alone.

@BearRightScum @ThoreaulyAwake @DanFriedman81 @JakeAnbinder Even if you are going to be that insular, the US was involved in WWII. What is your cutoff for history being relevant? The ancient Greeks and Romans are out. Thousands of years ago and on another continent. The Middle Ages? Who needs it, not like history ever repeats itself
@joshgondelman You might also need to double check that it hasn’t developed tiny, sentient life forms (ala Horton Hears a Who) before chucking it.

@keara_dunne @TribalSpaceCat @deadeyebrakeman I don’t think flattering bangs for very curly hair exist. Also, bangs are absolutely high commitment, how don you get rid of them? (I have no idea what you’re describing with dying clip ins, so maybe that’s the answer for people who don’t insist on extremes of low maintenance 😝)

@awaisaftab @QuantPsychiatry I have an N of 1 subject, but a large amount of within subject data 😂. I did not suspect a seasonal pattern when I began tracking. Now that I have 2.5 years worth of data, the alignment from year to year is almost disturbing. But I am bipolarish, not MDD (and seasonal != SAD).

@DrGipps @DrT_Gergel @LiviaDePicker @TornadoNate you can be dangerously unwell with physical illness and feel just fine. For instance, many cancers cause few symptoms until a late stage, also diabetes etc. I know people who developed pre-eclampsia, with blood pressure levels requiring immediate hospitalization, and no symptoms.
@johnmoe I am very, very comfortable with just discovering things and getting super excited about them after they are already over, and no one else cares 😂 https://t.co/maKaRvK9UZ

@ryanmdelaney @AriannaRebolini @amandaeyreward I think different people find different stages more or less taxing or rewarding. I found babies hard because they need something ALL the time, but also easy because what they need is only ever one of three things. The older the kids get, the more complicated their needs are.

@FromPhDtoLife I think it implies the bare minimum of guaranteed funding of *some* sort, and also not having to pay tuition. There are PhD programs that guarantee money for only the first year, or an amount that does not cover full tuition let alone a stipend (thus “partially” funded)

@awaisaftab Cases where it appears to work and then appears to stop working are particularly troublesome. I’ve had an initial strong sense that a medication was helping that later seemed ambiguous. But, I also have the curse of studying causal reasoning (among other things) professionally :)

@awaisaftab I find (i) compelling, but (ii) I always worry about causal illusions of timing. It’s like how parents of infants, desperate for sleep, successively try every possible sleep remedy. One way or another, eventually the baby sleeps, and they become zealots for the last thing tried

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD To be clear, when I say it took 24 years to get the diagnosis, it wasn’t because it was ambiguous. I never tried to get a diagnosis. I just kept trying to run the marathon.

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD It’s like running a marathon with glass in your legs, and you’re like this really fucking hurts, and everyone’s like of course, it’s a marathon, push through it, because they can’t see inside your legs. And you can’t see inside theirs, so maybe this is what everyone’s feeling?

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD What spurred my recent bout of therapy is that two people confided in me that they knew their own depression was serious because they’d started having suicidal ideation. And I thought wait, that’s a big deal?   You mean I could not be constantly thinking about killing myself?

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD That’s what I thought. But now I’ve been told that most human beings aren’t plunged into months long states of desperate, endless, misery and self loathing so deep they’re pretty sure they’re not human beings at all, but something repulsive and pitiable, like Kafka’s cockroach.

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD I guess that’s fair, but it took those same 24 years to figure out I was bipolar (bipolar II, no full mania or psychosis). Until then, I thought I was just someone with ADHD and severe recurrent depression.

@endopendent @JakeGoodmanMD Yes, though Wellbutrin may be somewhat less likely to trigger manic or mixed states than SSRIs (which is why I tried it, since there was already some suspicion of bipolarity). But, however I became bipolarish, it wasn’t the result of SSRIs, or of any medication for that matter.
@DisabilityStor1 Why are you me?

@endopendent @JakeGoodmanMD I have bipolar 2 and I’ve never taken an SSRI. The only antidepressant I’ve ever taken is a very brief trial of Wellbutrin (not an SSRI or SNRI), which did make things worse, which is why it was brief, but that was already after 24 years of fully unmedicated symptoms.

@BNewtonUK @JakeGoodmanMD I was very high functioning, while increasingly considering killing myself. You‘d never guess. Multiple rounds of therapy. On the other hand, behaviours that are seen as inconsiderate by most people *can* absolutely be caused by mental illness—interrupting, talking too much, being late or missing appointments, not responding, being impatient or irritable etc.

@BusStopJaypass @swamp_cryptid @NoLore @h_shriya This is the definition of survivorship bias. Yes, you and everyone else on Twitter who biked to school as a kid survived, by definition. Because the kids who died in a bike accident sure aren’t posting. If a process has attrition, you can’t sample only the people who made it.

@grumpyshrubbery Regularly at a 9 pre-kids, it felt like waking up in active labor. I used to chew wildly unhealthy amounts of ibuprofen (like 2400mg at once), because swallowing took way too long. Something about giving birth helped, and now it’s a 1-3.

@dranniehickox I love Carrie Fisher, and I’m all about evidence based treatments, but the article makes a number of incorrect statements, the biggest one being that in fact childhood trauma (in addition to genetic/bio factors) does increase the risk of developing bipolar.
@Tara_Moss Totally, I was just musing on the two different senses in which I see myself as disabled. But, I didn’t mean to “well, actually” your point!

@Tara_Moss I find differently-abled very clunky, and don’t use it, but I do see my ADHD as pretty literally being differently abled. If society were different, I wouldn’t need accommodations. I believe being bipolar would always be disabling for me.

@Tara_Moss I find this personally complicated. I’m neurodivergent—my ADHD brain is better at some things and worse at others, just like all brains, but society is not set up for my kind of brain, so I need accommodations. My bipolar on the other hand, is a disability.
